intro: Asystasiella africana, commonly known as the African mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on a variety of host trees in sub-Saharan Africa. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and has small, oval-shaped leaves that are usually opposite in arrangement. The plant produces small white or pale yellow flowers, followed by fleshy, berry-like fruits that are dispersed by birds. Its roots penetrate the host's vascular system to extract water and nutrients, while still performing some photosynthesis. Asystasiella africana plays a role in local ecosystems by providing food for birds and other animals.
